Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: A Unified Approach to the Euler-Mahonian Identity
Award.AbstractNarration:
A permutation of a finite set is a reordering of the elements of the set. Permutation statistics, such as descent number and major index, describe the behavior of a particular permutation. The Euler-Mahonian identity is a mathematical identity related to these permutation statistics which arises in many distinct areas of mathematics. This project will investigate the underlying connections between the different mathematical areas by identifying connections between the various proofs of the identity. The identification of such connections will allow for a more standard approach when studying other, often more difficult, mathematical identities of this type. Research will be conducted with Professor Takayuki Hibi, an expert in combinatorial mathematics, at Osaka University.

More explicitly, the Euler-Mahonian identity is a multivariate generating function identity involving the joint distribution of the descent number and major index over symmetric group Sn. The researcher plans to investigate connects between three proofs of the identity, namely (1) a method involving counting integer points in convex/discrete geometry, (2) a method involving commutative algebraic and representation theoretic techniques in the context of the coinvariant algebra for the symmetric group Sn, and (3) a method involving finding ordinary generating functions arising from lecture hall partitions. The identification of such connections will allow for extending to similar, but more complicated combinatorial identities of this type, such as those involving statistics of the hyperoctohedral group or colored permutation groups. Professor Hibi, along with his research group at Osaka University, are leaders in algebraic combinatorics and combinatorial commutative algebra. Subsequently, Professor Hibi?s insight and expertise will be an invaluable aid in developing a unified approach to generating functions of this type.

This award under the East Asia and Pacific Summer Institutes program supports summer research by a U.S. graduate student and is jointly funded by NSF and the Japan Society for the Promotion of Science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The proposed vision of this project was to work towards a unified approach to Euler-Mahonian identities. Given a finite set, a permutation is a way reording the elements of that set. Permutation statistics, such as the descent number and major index, are values, which describe the beahvior of a given permutation. Euler-Mahonian identities are mathematical identities, which arise from the descent number and major index permutation statistics, as well as certain generalizations.

These Euler- Mahonian identities arise in many mathematical contexts that do not seem to be otherwise connected. The specific goal of this project was to try to connect the mathematics behind three different methods of proof, by way of producing new proofs of the identities by merging the existing methods into new contexts. Of our three proposed connections, we were successful in showing one of them.

Throughout the course of this project, the focus shifted away from studying these Euler-Mahonian identities in favor of studying certain discrete geometric objects known as convex lattice polytopes. In particular, the PI studied a certain family of convex lattice polytopes known as s-lecture hall polytopes. These objects arose when we were working on our original goals and it became clear that studying properties of these polytopes would prove more fruitful and interesting.

We showed that certain families of these s-lecture hall polytopes exhibit certain algebraic and geometric properties. In particular, for certain families of these polytopes, we characterized when s-lecture hall polytopes have the reflexive or Gorenstein properties. These properties are of interest for both geometric and algebraic reasons. Additionally, we showed that a large family of s-lecture hall polytopes have the integer decomposition property (IDP). Having the IDP is a useful additive structure on the polytope, and knowing which polytopes exhibit this property is of interest in combinatorial commutative algebra.

In conclusion, we were able to partially accomplish the initial goals of project and we were able to make progress on different problems not initially within the scope of the project. This project has resulted in four co-authored papers submitted for publication at peer-reviewed journals.
